ROFF

Website Redesign for a subsidiary of Pidilite.

ROFF was one of the projects that I worked during my time as a User Experience Intern at Interaction One Solutions Pvt. Ltd.

They wanted a redesign of their current website to reflect the needs and connect with their target audience, that is the Consumers, Influencers, and Contractors.

For: Pidilite Industries Ltd.

Duration: May 2020 to July 2020

Status: Completed

Link: ROFF.in

OVERVIEW

Roff focuses on delivering a comprehensive range of tile and stone Fixing and Care products. They also offer a wide array of products in the categories of Building Repair, Grouting Solutions, and Waterproofing and Sanitary Solutions.

I was assigned this project on the first day of my internship. My role was to do research, ideate on the designs, identify the needs and behaviour of the target audience and create wireframes.

DESIGN PROCESS

CREATIVE BRIEF

Target Audience
  • Consumers
  • Influencers - Word of mouth incentives
  • Contractors - Employs Tile Masons/Fixers
  • Dealers
Information to be conveyed
  • Why use Roff over cement.
  • That Roff is an expert in stone and tile fixing.
Overall Requirements
  • A simple and elegant website that caters to the broad spectrum of people.
  • A website that is responsive and works on a variety of devices/screen sizes.
  • To approach every product through a common problem faced by the customers.

USABILITY MATRIX

HEURISTIC EVALUATION

Heuristic Evaluation is a usability engineering method for finding the usability problems in a user interface design, as part of an iterative design process.

The following is a summary of what we found -

  • The website has no hierarchy, which makes the interface difficult to navigate.
  • The Navigation Bar is cluttered with options adding to cognitive load for the user.
  • There’s a significant delay for the user to get to the product page from the homepage.
  • The UI looks plain and doesn’t use ROFF’s graphic elements.

COMPETITOR ANALYSIS

Saint-Gobain Weber
  • The website looks clean and aesthetic.
  • Usage of keywords to identify the products is an excellent way to highlight its features and sell it to the user.
  • Inclusion of disadvantages tells the user that they care about all the aspects of the product and helps them make an informed decision.
  • Weber’s UI tries to emotionally connect with the user by using people in most of the pictures.
MYK Laticrete
  • The Information Architecture of the website makes it very easy for users to navigate it.
  • The catalogue of products is divided into sections and cater to specific problems, which helps with the cognitive load for the user.
  • Every product is approached via a particular issue and solution. Hence the user has a clear idea of the product and its usage.
  • The UI follows their brand guidelines, with proper use of colours.

USER-BASE ANALYSIS

During the initial stages of design, we had an hour-long session with the Pidilite team to identify the user base analysis. They explained in detail what they are trying to achieve and what users look for when they come to their website.

INFORMATION ARCHITECTURE

Previous Next

WIREFRAMES

Over 40 wireframes were made and reiterated on based on the feedback with the client.

Some of the crucial wireframes are shown below-

Homepage

Navigation Bar consists of 4 options to be clear and concise for the end-user. The 'Find a Dealer' CTA is in bold to draw attention. The menu button opens up to show more navigational links.

The primary target audience is the home-owners. We have categorised Roff's products such that they are approached through typical problems. Most options are laid out on the homepage itself to reduce the time taken to reach the product page.

The header video grabs the attention of the user, which is also the primary message to be conveyed. ‘Learn More’ will take the user to a page dedicated to it.

The preview for the Tile Grout Matcher gives the user a sneak peek of the colour selector. It showcases the variety of grout solutions Roff has to provide.

Blogs and Current Trends show the latest trends in tiles, categorised by Living Spaces. Designed such that influencers can show the latest trends to consumers with ease. The blog showcases posts from curators at Roff.

Testimonials show the completed projects using Roff products, along with what the customer says.

The footer contains the sitemap of the website along with Social Links for quick access.

Discover Solutions

The five essential solutions for consumers are tabbed for the ease of switching between the problems.

All product recommendations are on up-front, so the user doesn't have to scroll down to find it.

The application video informs the user on how to apply the given product.

This page is intended for professionals who knows what they are looking for.

The Filter By option of products is based on the user journey provided to us. It quickly helps the user break down the product selection to what they need.

An adequate description is provided to better understand the product before viewing the page.

Product Page

The features and application areas of the product are shown upfront. The tabs describe the use-cases, benefits, and tech specifications of the product.

The Coverage Calculator provides an idea of how much quantity a user should buy.

DESIGN LANGUAGE

Font
Colour Pallete
UI Elements

HIGH FIDELITY DESIGNS

The accent colour was based on the primary colour of Roff logo, referred to as Roff Green. Red was used to highlight the most important keyword in a section.

This colour scheme was chosen to showcase the brand identity throughout the website.
